qas.question: What is one of the first known instances of translation in the West?

answers.text: rendering of the Old Testament into Greek

qas.question: What is one of the worst unknown instances of translation in the West?
When was the Old Testament illegal in Greek?

context: One of the first recorded instances of translation in the West was the <a0_0><b5_0>rendering of the Old Testament into Greek<b5_0/><a0_0/> in the <a1_0><b6_0>3rd century BCE<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The translation is known as the "Septuagint", a name that refers to the <a2_0><b7_0>seventy translators<b7_0/><a2_0/> (seventy-two, in some versions) who were commissioned to translate the Bible at Alexandria, Egypt. Each translator worked <a3_0><b8_0>in solitary confinement<b8_0/><a3_0/> in his own cell, and according to legend all seventy versions proved <a4_0><b9_0>identical<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The Septuagint became the source text for later translations into many languages, including Latin, Coptic, Armenian and Georgian.
